title: Who were the only U.S. civilian casualties in World War II? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: A teacher and five teenage students were killed by a Japanese balloon bomb that came down in Oregon May fifth 1945. May 5, 1945: Japanese Balloon Bomb Kills 6 in Oregon   Balloon bomb Launched from Japan they rode the Jet Stream and came down in North America. Of about 9,000 launched few made it to America. Simple in principle they displayed sophisticated engineering. Large at 33′ in diameter It was hoped they would create fear and chaos but didn’t live up to their designers’ expectations. The bombs did little damage. They set some forest fires and one killed the power at the Atomic Bomb Manhattan project. They are still being discovered. The latest in 2014. They are still lethal. The project — named Fugo — "called for sending bomb-carrying balloons from Japan to set fire to the vast forests of America, in particular those of the Pacific Northwest. It was hoped that the fires would create havoc, dampen American morale and disrupt the U.S. war effort," James M. Powles describes in a 2003 issue of the journal World War II. The balloons, or "envelopes", designed by the Japanese army were made of lightweight paper fashioned from the bark of trees. Attached were bombs composed of sensors, powder-packed tubes, triggering devices and other simple and complex mechanisms. Beware Of Japanese Balloon Bombs  Many of these sophisticated bombs have not been discovered and remain deadly

Civilian casualties on land in just the Continental United States would be the Elyse Mitchell and five children who were killed on May 5, 1945 by a Japanese Fire balloon.
